thread.title: Trumansburg girls advance to Class C soccer semis
thread.title_full: Trumansburg girls advance to Class C soccer semis

title: Trumansburg girls advance to Class C soccer semis
text:
Trumansburg girls advance to Class C soccer semis Tom Fleischman, tfleischman@ithacajournal.com | @TomF_IJSports 7:49 p.m. EDT October 23, 2015 Trumansburg raced to a 3-0 halftime lead en route to a 5-0 victory over Bainbridge-Guilford in the Section 4 Class C girls' soccer quarterfinals. The Raiders will meet Elmira Notre Dame in the semis. Buy Photo Lansing's Megan Dean, center, celebrates scoring the first goal of their 2-0 win over Groton, Friday afternoon in Lansing. (Photo: SIMON WHEELER / Staff Photo) Buy Photo Story Highlights Bainbridge-Guilford arrived late in Trumansburg, and fell behind 1-0 just five minutes into the game Freshman Finley Edmonds scored a hat trick for the Blue Raiders, who led 3-0 at halftime Trumansburg will play top seed Elmira Notre Dame on Tuesday in the Class C semifinals in Elmira Defending champ Lansing advanced to Tuesday's semifinals with a 2-0 victory over IAC rival Groton CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The day began with a two-hour bus ride and a late arrival in Trumansburg, and things just went from bad to worse for the Bainbridge-Guilford girls' soccer team. 
Freshman Finley Edmonds scored the first of her three goals just five minutes into the game, and the host Blue Raiders went on to defeat the Bobcats, 5-0, in the quarterfinals of the Section 4 Class C tournament at Tarbell Stadium. 
Freshman Jenna Seafuse and sophomore Taylor Miller also scored goals for the Blue Raiders (11-5-0), who took a 3-0 lead at halftime and controlled play throughout. Sophomore goalie Madison Mikula earned the shutout with a six-save effort, including a diving stop to the right post to preserve the shutout with just over three minutes left. 
"We actually played really good team defense," T-burg coach Scott Stewart said. "Our outside midfielders did a good job of carrying the ball down the side and crossing it in. Our center mids played really well, too, they kept the ball at their feet and controlled the pace of the game. I think that was the difference in the game, really." 
The Bobcats (9-7-1), who got a yeoman 20-save effort from sophomore keeper Megan Palmatier, didn't get off the bus till around 3 p.m. for a 3:30 start, and Stewart thought that played a role in the visitors' slow start. 
"That first score really made a difference, and it looked like B-G wasn't really into the game," he said. "They got here late, and I think they were a little flat when they came out. And then once they got behind 3-0, that was kind of hard for them. And having a two-hour bus ride, that didn't help." 
The Blue Raiders extended their win streak to three games since losing back-to-back games to sectional powers Dryden and Lansing, and are primed for a rematch with top-seeded Elmira Notre Dame, who advanced on Friday with a 7-0 victory over Sidney. The 15th-ranked Crusaders topped T-burg in the final of the Lady Crusader Tournament in mid-September, and Stewart relishes the opportunity for another shot at them. 
"We're coming at a good time," he said. "We really want to get back to playing (Notre Dame) again and showing them what we can do. I respect Steve (Weber, END coach) and the program over there tremendously, they have a really good program. To go over there and give them some hell, so to speak, that's our goal." 
Lansing 2, Groton 0: At Lansing, Megan Dean and Liz Barre scored first-half goals and the Bobcat defense neutralized Indians leading scorer Sidney Reeves to advance to Tuesday's Class C semifinals. 
Kassie Riemer assisted on both goals for Lansing (12-4-1), which outshot Groton, 18-2, and had a 6-3 edge in corners. Lena Gisler stopped both shots she saw for the winners, while Paige Graham had 14 saves for Groton. Buy Photo 
Lansing's Jill Austin, and Groton's Lauren Reeves battle for position under the ball Friday afternoon during Lansing's 2-0 win in the Section IV playoffs in Lansing. (Photo: SIMON WHEELER / Staff Photo) 
"We got out to a quick lead, and I was able to get a good number of subs in in the first half," Lansing first-year coach Ken Kutler said. "I thought that maybe we could jump on them in the second half, but we couldn't." 
Lansing beat Groton in the season-opener, 7-1, but Friday's was a different game, Kutler said. 
"They (Groton) played well, as good as I've seen them play," he said. "They were very motivated to play this game. And the Reeves sisters (Sidney and Lauren) gave us fits." 
Sidney Reeves nearly cut the deficit to one goal for the Indians (10-6) with a free kick in the late going, from about 20 yards out, but she put the ball over the crossbar. "I thought it was going to be 2-1." 
Lansing, the defending sectional champ and last year's state Class C runner-up, will take on either third seed Unadilla Valley or sixth seed Marathon at 3:30 p.m. Tuesday in Lansing. The championship game is next Friday in Norwich. Read or Share this story: http://ithacajr.nl/1LT6NnW TOP VIDEOS
